bibl.title: Report [on fever cases] by Frederick A. Miller, March 19, 1923

div1.p: Miller reports on a possible yellow fever outbreak in Colombia.

div1.head: Report [on fever cases] by Frederick A. Miller, March 19, 1923
div1.p:
On Wednesday, March 7, 1923, an article appeared in a local newspaper
saying that there had appeared in Bucaramanga, the Capital of Santander, about
twenty cases with eight deaths of a disease that manifested itself, by quick onset,
high fever, vomiting of blood (black vomit) and albumin in the urine.

At this time I went to Dr. Garcia Medina, the Director of National Hygiene,
and asked him whether I should cable the Board to send a commission to investigate
this affair. In the absence of any data or official information, he replied
that it was not necessary and that we should wait for further information. In
the meantime Dr. Garcia had cabled and telegraphed to all possible places from
which a case might originate and receiving a negative reply and as the distance
from any infected area to Bucaramanga is more than twelve days, he ruled out
yellow fever.

From data secured from Bucaramanga it seems that this disease first
appeared as a single case in November 1922, and with two more cases in December.
From January 1 to March 7 there appeared seventy more cases with twenty deaths,
although sixty of these cases did not show any vomiting of blood.

Follows the manifestation of the disease from official reports to Dr.
Garcia: Quick onset with chills and fever; the temperature rising rapidly to
39 and 40C; intense frontal headaches and superorbital pain on pressure; move-
ments of the abdominal muscles; skin very hot and dry; sudden rash; anorexia;
constipation and abdominal pain; the temperature falls on the third day and comes
to normal on the fifth or sixth day with much sweating; generally on the third day
appear pains in the epigastric region and over the liver and a low grade jaundice;
vomiting present in all cases. Some cases pursue a worse course, and black vomit
presents itself on the third day with melenic evacuations. The patient is gener-
ally very anxious: albumin is intense and rapid, increasing until death; pulse
slow at first full and strong, later depressed and disappears; jaundice accentuated;
urine without any biliary pigments, albumin abundant up to twelve per thousand,
- 2 -
oliguria and anuria in some cases; hemorrhages in all the mucous membranes and ecchy-
moses; delirium terminating in coma.
There were approximately twenty cases of black vomit all of which were fatal.

Autopsies only show a slightly bloody fluid in the intestinal tract and
a congestion of the gastric mucous membrane; the liver pallid.

On account of the lack of any definite autopsy findings, Dr. Garcia is
of the opinion that this disease is the same that appeared in Muzo in 1916 when
Drs. Gorgas and Carter came here to investigate and decided that it was not yellow
fever but a form of malaria.

Bucaramanga is approximately three days on horseback from Puerto Wilches
the river port on the Magdalena River. Puerto Wilches is five days from the coast
town of Barranquilla and the nearest foreign port is Colon. Steamers coming from
Colon take three days so that it would require at least eleven days to reach Buca-
ramanga. From Buenaventura on the Pacific coast is at least twelve days, and there
has been no yellow fever in Buenaventura for at least three years.
